1790.note: Enumeration was conducted by U.S. Marshals in counties or judicial districts. Vermont was not yet included until 1791. Indian lands were generally excluded unless considered taxable.

1800.note: Enumeration was conducted within counties or territorial districts where applicable. Coverage expanded with the inclusion of new states like Kentucky and Tennessee. Indian lands were excluded unless under civil jurisdiction.

1810.note: Enumeration occurred by county or local districts, including newly acquired Orleans Territory from the Louisiana Purchase. Indian lands were typically excluded.

1820.note: Enumeration was done by counties, districts, and settlements. Missouri and Arkansas territories were included. Indian lands remained outside of enumeration unless settled.

1830.note: Enumeration was standardized using printed forms and conducted by counties, parishes, and other civil divisions. Indian territories were not fully enumerated.

1840.note: Enumeration was conducted by counties or equivalent civil divisions, using standardized forms. Institutional populations were included through special inquiries. Indian lands were excluded unless individuals lived under state jurisdiction.

1850.note: Enumeration done by counties and townships. Slave schedules used in slave states. Indian reservations were not systematically included.

1860.note: Enumeration units were counties and townships. Frontier areas included as states and territories expanded westward. Indian lands were not enumerated unless integrated into states.

1870.note: Enumeration occurred by counties and districts. Challenges existed in Southern states due to Reconstruction. Indian lands were included only if under civil authority.

1880.note: Enumeration conducted by trained census agents using counties and subdivisions. Indian lands were still generally excluded unless under U.S. jurisdiction.

1890.note: Enumeration units were counties, reservations, and federal jurisdictions. Indian lands were enumerated separately using special Indian schedules. Most data lost due to 1921 fire.

1900.note: Enumeration conducted in all states and territories, including newly annexed Hawaii and Puerto Rico. Enumeration units were counties, parishes, and reservations. Indian lands covered by distinct enumeration procedures.

1910.note: Enumeration was organized by counties, wards, reservations, and special areas. Indian lands were included through separate schedules and designated agents.

1920.note: Enumeration based on counties, cities, and districts. Indian lands included through targeted enumeration methods.

1930.note: Enumeration organized by counties, reservations, and civil districts. Indian lands systematically included using specialized forms.

1940.note: Enumeration based on counties and enumeration districts. Indian lands were included through assigned field agents.

1950.note: Enumeration based on counties, cities, and census tracts. Indian lands included under federal oversight using local agents.

1960.note: Continued use of census tracts and enumeration districts. Coverage extended to Indian lands under federal administration.

1970.note: Enumeration conducted via mailed questionnaires with follow-up interviews. Indian lands included via local enumeration districts.

1980.note: Enumeration used mail-back forms, field visits, and outreach for hard-to-count areas. Indian reservations and trust lands included in dedicated enumeration areas.

1990.note: Enumeration conducted primarily through mailed surveys and in-person follow-up. Geographic units included counties, reservations, census blocks. Indian lands covered through designated enumeration areas.
